question: I don't want to hear anymore about it. I'm not going, and that's final.
answer: Excuse me, excuse me...there will be plenty of time for questions later... I'm Captain John Harriman. I'd like to welcome you all aboard.

question: It's our pleasure.
answer: I just want you to know how excited we all are to have a group of living legends with us on our maiden voyage. I remember reading about your missions when I was in grade school.

question: Well... may we have a look around?
answer: Please... please.

question: Damn fine ship if you ask me...
answer: You know, Scotty... it amazes me.

question: And what would that be, sir?
answer: Sulu. When did he find the time for a family?

question: It's like you always said -- if something's important enough, you make the time. So... that's why you've been running around the galaxy like an eighteen-year-old. Finding retirement a little lonely, are we?
answer: With that kind of tact, I'm glad you're an engineer and not a psychiatrist.

question: With that kind of tact, I'm glad you're an engineer and not a psychiatrist.
answer: Excuse me, gentlemen... if you'll take your seats.

question: Oh... of course.
answer: Prepare to leave spacedock. Aft thrusters ahead one quarter, port and starboard at station keeping. Captain Kirk, I'd be honored if you would give the order to get underway.

question: No... no. Thank you.
answer: Please, I insist.

question: We'll have to keep our distance... we don't want to get pulled in too...
answer: Tractor beam...

question: We don't have a tractor beam.
answer: You left spacedock without a tractor beam?

question: Captain Kirk... I would appreciate any... suggestions you might have.
answer: First -- move us within transporter range and beam those people to the Enterprise.

question: What about the gravimetric distortions? They'll tear us apart...
answer: Risk is part of the game if you want to sit in that chair.

question: Helm, close to within transporter range.
answer: And second -- turn that damned thing off.

question: But I do have a theory...
answer: I thought you might.

question: An anti-matter discharge directly ahead... it might disrupt the field long enough for us to break away.
answer: A photon torpedo?

question: Aye.
answer: Load torpedo bays, prepare to fire on my command.

question: But the sharks are quite convincing.
answer: Doctor, I must confess I am uncertain as to why pushing someone into freezing, shark- infested water is amusing.

question: It's all done in good fun, Data. Get in the spirit of things.
answer: Ah.

question: You see the top yardarm, now look to the --
answer: Bridge to Commander Riker.

question: Riker here.
answer: We're picking up a distress call from the Amargosa observatory, sir. They say they're under attack.

question: Is she still angry?
answer: No... but I'd stay out of Sickbay for a while if I were you. I still don't know why you dropped her in the water.

question: I was attempting to... get in the spirit of things. I thought it would be humorous.
answer: Data... you're not thinking about using that thing are you?

question: It has occurred to me on several occasions. But I believe this may be the appropriate time.
answer: Wait a minute. I thought you've always been afraid it would overload your neural net.

question: That is true. However, I believe my growth as an artificial life form has reached an impasse. For thirty-four years I have endeavored to become more "human" - to grow beyond my original programming. And yet I am still unable to grasp such a simple concept as humor. This emotion chip is the only answer.
answer: All right... But at the first sign of trouble, I'm going to deactivate it. agreed?

question: We found two dead Romulans aboard the station. We're analyzing their equipment to see if we can determine what ship they came from.
answer: There's still no indication of why they attacked the station?

question: We think they were looking for something -- they practically tore the place apart.
answer: Hmm... Inform Starfleet Command. This could indicate a new Romulan threat in this sector.

question: You want me to contact Starfleet?
answer: Is there a problem?

question: No, sir.
answer: Thank you, Number One.

question: There is something else, Captain. One of the scientists. a Doctor Soran... has insisted on speaking with you. I told him you were busy, sir, but he said it was absolutely imperative that he speak with you right away.
answer: Understood. That will be all.

question: Sir... is there anything wrong?
answer: No. Thank you.

question: Doctor Soran...?
answer: Yes, yes, Captain -- thank you for coming.

question: Nothing for me. I understand there's something urgent you need to discuss with me.
answer: Yes. I need to return to the observatory immediately. I must continue a critical experiment I was running on the Amargosa star.

question: Doctor... we're still conducting an investigation into the attack. Once we've completed our work, we'll be happy to allow you and your fellow scientists back aboard the observatory. Until then --
answer: The timing is very important on my experiment -- if it is not completed within the next twelve hours, years of research will be lost.

question: We're doing the best we can. Now if you'll excuse me...
answer: They say time is the fire in which we burn... and right now, Captain, my time is running out. We leave so many things unfinished in our lives -- I'm sure you can understand.

question: One of the dead Romulans had a tricorder. We analyzed its sensor logs and found they were scanning for signature particles of a compound called trilithium.
answer: Trilithium?

question: An experimental compound the Romulans have been working on. In theory, a trilithium-based explosive would be thousands of times more powerful than an anti-matter weapon. But they never found a way to stabilize it.
answer: Why were they looking for it on a Federation observatory? It doesn't make any sense. Have Geordi and Data go over with the next Away Team... tell them to scan the observatory for trilithium.

question: There's no sign of any trilithium in here.
answer: I get it. I get it.

question: You get what?
answer: When you said to Commander Riker... "The clown can stay, but the Ferengi in the gorilla suit has to go."

question: What?
answer: During the Farpoint mission. We were on the Bridge and you told a joke. That was the punch line.

question: The Farpoint mission? Data, that was seven years ago.
answer: I know. I just got it. It was very funny.

question: Thanks. Wait a minute... there's a hidden doorway here. I can see the joint of the metal with my VISOR.
answer: There appears to be a dampening field in operation. I cannot scan beyond the bulkhead.

question: I don't see a control panel...or an access port.
answer: It appears to be a magnetically sealed. I believe I can reverse the polarity by attenuating my axial servo. "Open sesame." You could say I have a... magnetic personality.

question: I'm still not picking up anything. Someone went to a lot of trouble to shield this room. Data, take a look at this. You ever seen a solar probe with this kind of configuration?
answer: No, Geordi. I have not. It is most unusual.

question: Just help me get this panel open. Whoa. my VISOR'S picking up something in the theta band...it could be a trilithium signature. Data, this isn't the time...
answer: I am sorry... but I cannot stop myself... I think something is wrong...

question: Data! Data, are you all right?
answer: I believe the emotional chip has overloaded my positronic relays.

question: Tea. Earl Grey. Hot. Come. Counselor. What can I do for you?
answer: Actually... I'm here to see if there's anything I can do for you.

question: Well... I appreciate your concern, but I'd rather not discuss it right now, thank you.
answer: I'm afraid I can't just leave it at that. The commanding officer of this ship is clearly distraught about something. As ship's Counselor, it's my duty to --

question: As ship's counselor, it's your duty to know not only when you're needed... but also when you're not.
answer: You can't fool an empath, Captain. I know exactly when I'm needed.

question: Well, with all due respect to your Betazoid senses, I prefer to be alone right now.
answer: Very well. I suppose I could make out my weekly report to Starfleet Command without your input. "Admiral Lusby... regarding the unusual behavior of Jean-Luc Picard

question: All right, all right. You've made your point. The message I received... My brother... and his son -- my nephew -- burned to death in a fire.
answer: Captain, I'm sorry. I know there were a lot of unresolved conflicts between you and your brother.

question: What I can't get out of my mind is the image of Rene -- my nephew. I just can't believe he's gone...
answer: It's only natural to feel a heightened sense of tragedy when a child dies... But it goes deeper than that, doesn't it? I can sense that Rene meant a great deal to you.

question: In a way, he was as close as I ever came to having a child of my own.
answer: Your family history is very important to you, isn't it?

question: Ever since I was a little boy, I remember hearing about the family line. The Picards that fought at Trafalgar... the Picard's that settled the first Martian colony. When my brother married and had a son...
answer: ... You felt it was no longer your responsibility to carry on the family line.

question: My brother had shouldered that burden... allowing me to pursue my own selfish needs...
answer: There's nothing selfish about pursuing your own life... your own career.

question: You know, Counselor... I'm not getting any younger. For some time now, I've been aware that there are fewer days ahead than there are behind... But I always took comfort in the fact that when I was gone, my family would continue. But now... I've had brushes with death... more than I care to contemplate. I always accepted it as a calculated risk that goes along with wearing this uniform. But now... the idea of death has a terrible sense of finality to it. I'm the last Picard.
answer: Captain, perhaps we --

question: Soran? That's a name I haven't heard in a long time.
answer: Do you remember him?

question: Oh yes. I remember everyone who was on the Lakul... every face. even the ones who didn't make it...
answer: Guinan. It's important that you tell me what you know. We think Soran's developed a weapon... a terrible weapon. It might give him enough power to --

question: Soran doesn't care about power or weapons. All he cares about is getting back to the Nexus.
answer: What's the "Nexus"?

question: It's a place I've tried very hard to forget... That ribbon isn't just some random energy phenomenon traveling through space... it's a doorway. It leads to another place... the Nexus. It doesn't exist in our Universe... and it doesn't play by the same rules either.
answer: What happened to you?

question: I can't remember very much... what it looked like or how long I was there... but I do remember how it felt... It was like being inside... joy. As if joy was a real thing that I could wrap around myself. I've never been so content...
answer: But then you were beamed away...

question: I was pulled away. I didn't want to leave; none of us did. I felt like I'd left a part of myself behind. All I could think about was getting back... I didn't care what I had to do. It took a long time, but eventually I learned to live with it. And I began to realize that my experience in the Nexus had changed me... I knew things about people... about events...about time...
answer: Your "sixth sense"... I've always wondered where it came from... And what about Soran?

question: Soran may still be obsessed with getting back. And if he is, he'll do anything to find that doorway again.
answer: But why destroy a star...? Thank you, Guinan.

question: A remarkable piece of equipment... but a little inelegant, wouldn't you say? Have you ever considered a prosthesis that would make you look a little more... normal?
answer: What's normal?

question: Normal is what everyone else is... and what you are not.
answer: What do you want?

question: As you may or may not be aware, I am an El-Aurian. Some people call us a race of "listeners". We listen. Right now, Mr. La Forge, you have my undivided attention. I want to listen to everything you know about trilithium. and me.
answer: Trilithium is an experimental compound developed by the Romulans. I think it's a derivative of --

question: I don't want a science lecture. You were on that observatory looking for trilithium... why?
answer: I was ordered to by the Captain.

question: Let's try to move beyond the usual prisoner-interrogator banter, shall we? You have information, and I need it. Did the Captain explain his orders to you? Did he say why you were searching for trilithium?
answer: No.

question: What about... Guinan? What has she told you about me?
answer: Guinan? I don't know what you're talking about...

question: My instincts tell me you're lying. And I know that can't be easy for you... I can see you have a good heart. Oh... I forgot to tell you. While you were unconscious, I injected a nano-probe into your bloodstream. It's been navigating your cardiovascular system... and right now I've attached it to your left ventricle. A little trick I picked up from the Borg.
answer: Yeah... they're full of great ideas.

question: I just stopped your heart for five seconds. It felt like an eternity, didn't it? Did you know that you can stop the human heart for up to ten minutes before the onset of brain damage?
answer: No... I didn't know that...

question: We learn something new about ourselves every day. Now. Maybe I didn't make myself clear. It is very important that you tell me exactly what Captain Picard knows.
answer: I told you everything... you might as well just kill me right now...

question: According to our information, the ribbon is a conflux of temporal energy which travels through our galaxy every thirty-nine point one years
answer: When is it expected back? Data?

question: Sorry, Captain. The Ribbon has already entered the galaxy. It will pass through this sector in approximately thirty-one hours.
answer: Guinan said Soran was trying to get back to the ribbon... if that's true, then there must be some connection with the Amargosa star.

question: The star's destruction has had numerous astro-physical effects within this sector. However, none of them appear to have a connection to the energy ribbon.
answer: Give me a list of those effects. I want to know every single thing which has been altered or changed... no matter how insignificant...

question: It will take a few moments for the computer to compile the information.
answer: Data, are you all right?

question: No, sir. I am finding it difficult to concentrate... I believe I am overwhelmed with feelings of... remorse and regret concerning my actions on the observatory.
answer: What do you mean?

question: I wanted to save Geordi... I tried. but I experienced something I did not expect. I believe it was fear.
answer: Fear is a very difficult emotion to overcome. It's something we all have to learn to deal with.

question: But I did not deal with it, sir. I let it prevent me from helping my friend. Does that make me a coward?
answer: No. And what you must try to avoid is becoming consumed by another emotion which I believe you're beginning to experience... guilt.

question: Guilt. It is a most unpleasant feeling. According to our current information, the destruction of the Amargosa star has had the following effects in this sector
answer: Wait. The Bozeman... why did it change course?

question: The destruction of the Amargosa star has altered the gravitational forces throughout the sector. Any ship passing through this region will have to make a minor course correction.
answer: A minor course correction... Where is the ribbon now?

question: This is its current position.
answer: Can you project its course? Data. I have nothing but sympathy for what you're going through. But right now, I need your full attention on the task at hand. If you can't provide it... then I'll have to relieve you of duty until Doctor Crusher can remove this. emotion chip of yours. I'm sorry, but you leave me no other choice.

question: I do not wish to remove the chip, sir. Although these emotions are proving difficult to deal with... I cannot imagine going back to a life without them. I have taken an important step toward becoming truly human. If I were to turn back now... I would like to continue in my duties, sir.
answer: Courage is an emotion too, Data. Now... can you project the course of the ribbon?

question: I believe so.
answer: Enhance grid A-nine. Where was the Amargosa star? Now... you said the gravitational forces in this sector have been altered... could that also affect the course of the ribbon?

question: I believe so.
answer: That's what Soran's doing... he's changing its course. But why? Why try to alter its path... why not simply fly into it with a ship?

question: Our records show that every ship which has approached the ribbon has either been destroyed or severely damaged.
answer: He can't go to the ribbon... so he's trying to make the ribbon come to him. Data, is it going to pass near any M-Class planets?

question: Yes, sir. There are two in the Veridian system.
answer: It's very close to Veridian Three... but not close enough... Data, what would happen to the ribbon's path if he destroyed the Veridian star itself? That's where he's going.

question: It should be noted, sir, that the collapse of the Veridian star would produce a shock wave similar to the one we observed at Amargosa.
answer: And destroy every planet in the system. Are any of them inhabited?

question: Veridian Three is uninhabited. but Veridian Four supports a pre- industrial humanoid society.
answer: Population?

question: Approximately two hundred thirty million.
answer: Picard to Bridge. Red Alert, Mister Worf. Set a course for the Veridian system, maximum warp.

question: On screen.
answer: Captain. What an unexpected pleasure.

question: Lursa, I want to talk to Soran.
answer: I'm afraid the Doctor is no longer aboard our ship.

question: What you're about to do is no different from when the Borg destroyed your world.
answer: You're right. And there was a time when I wouldn't have hurt anyone. Then the Borg came... and they showed me that if there is one constant in this universe, it's death. Afterwards, I began to realize that none of it mattered. We're all going to die anyway. It's only a question of how and when. You will too, Captain. You might contract a fatal disease... you might die in battle... ... or burn to death in a fire. You looked surprised. But you shouldn't be. I've been to the Nexus, Captain. I know things about people. Aren't you beginning to feel time gaining on you? It's like a predator. It's stalking you. You can try to outrun it with doctors... medicines.new technologies... but in the end, time is going to hunt you down... and make the kill.

question: We're all. mortal, Soran. It's one of the truths of our existence.
answer: What if I told you I found a new truth...

question: The Nexus.
answer: Time has no meaning there. The predator has no teeth.

question: What's going on? Where am I? I... don't know what to say... Merry... Christmas... Oh yes... yes, it's astonishingly beautiful. All of it. Thank you... I can't imagine what it is. You mean a sextant. And it's a handsome one at that... from about eighteen twenty, I'd say. Wherever did you find it? Oh, a secret... well, that makes it a doubly special gift. Thank you... thank you all... No... this isn't right... this can't be real... Guinan... what's going on? Where am I?
answer: You're in the Nexus.

question: This... is the Nexus?
answer: For you. This is where you wanted to be...

question: But I never had a wife, children, a home like this...
answer: Enjoy them, Jean-Luc...

question: Guinan, what are you doing here? I thought you were on the Enterprise.
answer: I am on the Enterprise...I am also here. Think of me as... an "echo" of the person you know... a part of her she left behind...

question: Left behind...?
answer: When the Enterprise-B beamed us off the Lakul, we were partially in the Nexus. The transporters locked on to us... but somehow everyone left a part of themselves behind.

question: Soran...?
answer: All of us.

question: Where is he now?
answer: Wherever he wanted to be...

question: In a few minutes... These are my children... my children...
answer: Yeah. They're great, aren't they? You can go back and see them born... go forward and see your grandchildren... time has no meaning here.

question: Go on... go on without me... Guinan... can I leave the Nexus?
answer: Why would you want to leave?

question: Can I?
answer: Yes... where would you go?

question: I don't understand.
answer: I told you, time has no meaning here. If you leave, you can go anywhere... any time.

question: I know exactly where I want to go... and when. Back to that mountaintop on Veridian Three... before Soran put out the star. I have to stop him.
answer: What makes you think things will be any different this time?

question: You're right. I'll need help. Guinan, will you come back with me? Together, we could --
answer: I can't leave. I'm already there, remember? I know just the guy.

question: James Kirk.
answer: Beautiful day, isn't it?

question: Yes... yes, it is.
answer: Do you mind?

question: Oh. Captain, do you realize what --
answer: Wait a second. I think something's burning. Looks like someone was cooking eggs... Come on in, it's all right. This is my house -- or at least it used to be, I sold it years ago.

question: I'm Captain Jean-Luc Picard of the starship Enterprise.
answer: This clock... I gave this clock to Bones...

question: I'm from what you would consider the future... the twenty-fourth century.
answer: Jake! Jake, you miserable old Mutt... How can you be here? He's been dead seven years. That's Antonia... Wait a minute... The future... what are you talking about? This is the past... This is nine years ago... the day I told her I was going back to Starfleet... These were Ktarian eggs -- her favorite.I was cooking them to soften the blow... And I gave her this.

question: I know how real this must seem to you, but it's not. This isn't Really your house. We've both been caught up in some sort of temporal nexus.
answer: Dill weed. There's a bottle of dill weed on the second shelf to the left, right behind the nutmeg.

question: How long have you been here?
answer: I don't know. I was on the Enterprise-B... in the deflector control room... keep stirring these, will you? The bulkhead in front of me Disappeared... then I was out there chopping wood. Thanks.

question: History records that you died saving the Enterprise-B from an energy ribbon eighty years ago...
answer: So you're telling me this is the twenty-fourth century... and I'm dead?

question: Not exactly. As I said, this is some kind of...
answer: Temporal nexus... yeah, I heard you. Something's missing...

question: Captain, I need your help. I want you to leave the Nexus with me. We have to go back to a planet called Veridian III and stop a man from destroying a star. There are millions of lives at stake.
answer: You said history considers me dead. Who am I to argue with history?

question: You're a Starfleet Officer and you have a duty to --
answer: I don't need to be lectured by you. I was out saving the galaxy when your grandfather was still in diapers. And frankly, I think the galaxy owes me one I was like you once... so worried about duty and obligations that I couldn't see anything past this uniform. And in the end, what did it get me? Nothing. Not this time. I'm going to walk up these stairs, march into that bedroom and tell Antonia that I want to marry her. This time things are going to be different.

question: This doesn't look like your bedroom.
answer: No... no, it's not. It's better.

question: Better?
answer: This is my uncle's barn in Iowa... I took that horse out for a ride seven years ago... on a spring day. Just like this. If I'm right, this is the day I met Antonia. This Nexus of yours is very clever. I can start all over again -- do things right from day one. I must have made this jump fifty times. and every time it scared the hell out of me. But not this time. Because... it's not real.

question: Antonia?
answer: She's not real either, is she? Nothing here is... nothing here matters... It's kinda like... orbital skydiving. Exciting for a few minutes... but in the end, you haven't really done anything... you haven't made a difference... Captain of the Enterprise, huh?

question: That's right.
answer: Close to retirement?

question: I hadn't planned on it.
answer: Well, let me tell you something - don't. Don't let them promote you... don't let them transfer you... don't let anything take you off the Bridge of that ship... Because while you're there, you can make a difference.

question: You don't need to be on the Bridge of a starship. Come with me. Help me stop Soran. Make a difference again.
answer: How can I argue with the Captain of the Enterprise? What was the name of that Planet... Veridian III?

question: That's right.
answer: I take it the odds are against us, and the situation is grim?

question: You could say that.
answer: Of course, if Spock were here, he'd say I was being an irrational, illogical human for wanting to go on a mission like that... Sounds like fun.

question: Nice shot.
answer: I'll find a way to contact the Enterprise. You're going to be all right.

question: Did we do it? Did we make a Difference...?
answer: Yes. Thank you.

question: Least I could do...for a Captain of the Enterprise.
answer: Try to hang on.

question: Over here, Data! I think I've found something. One life sign, very faint.
answer: Spot. I am very happy to find you, Spot.

question: Another family reunited. Data... are you all right?
answer: I am not sure, Counselor. I am happy to see Spot... and yet I am crying. My emotional program must be malfunctioning again.
